CH
2'
Shanghai Nov 20 1934
Dear Family:
Again I'm writing from the air - this time on a trip to
chungkingâ€¢
I left Shanghai
this morning at 7.
We have one of
those
rarest of phenomenons -
a tail wind and made a fast trip to Nanking -
in fact we had to wait 10 minutes for the up river mail.
Our next
stop is Anking - then Kluklang and the end of this day's run at
My fellow passengers are a Swede and two Chinese - one of
the latter
Mr. Li was talking to me about his first trip in a plane
at Northampton,
I told him that city was familiar territory
for me
because I had
"Shake,
He said that he is the only Amherst graduate in Shanghai.
Wednesday Nov. 8lst.
We arrived at 1.30 and Howard Norris
the pilot with the aid of MeCleskey,
one of the up river pilots
persuaded me to join them in a round of
I was surprised and
delighted to find
arm did not bother me a bit and there is
no reason at all why I should not play as well (or as badly)
My play in Hankow was unbelievably bad but my right arm
had nothing to do with the quality - or rather lack of quality - of
the golf I
The Hankow Club is reputed to be
the best equip-
ped establishment of its kind in the Far East.
The club owns a traet
of 170 acres which was deeded to them years ago by the National
Government and some smart Scotchman - there are lots of Seots in
got the Government to stipulate in the deed that taxes on
the entire
(about $7.00 U.s.)
a similar
deal with the National
Government of Bolton Landing!
We are now approaching Ichang where we land to deliver mail
and then leaving Ichang we almost immediately start through the
gor ges
of the Yangtsze
and I will then spend all of my time having a "look-see"
at the grandest seenery I have ever viewed, with the single exception
one trip which I made with Lindbergh through the Canyon of the
Colorado.
In that flight we followed the river
canyon for about 500
miles,
occasionally going
below the rim.
Here the flight is
over 100 miles
gorges not as extensive as the Grand
nor as colorful - but entirely different.
Cornell Plant
in 1900 pioneered steamboating on the upper resches of the
Yangtze is authority for the statement that in the old days of ex-
clusive
junk traffic before any dangerous rocks
were blasted from the
that over 1000 men annually
lost their lives in the rapids.
waters of the Yangtze - a mile or more wide at points above and
below the gorges, are narrowed down
to as little as 200 yards at
places where the
solid rock cliffs rise straight up
on either
points the river has been known
to rise 180 feet in 24 hours.
You can
imagine the effect.
Later - Sunday Nov. 25th.
I arrived in Chungking Wednesday
at 3:30 p.m. and learned
that Debby and the girls had arrived
early in
the afternoon of the day before.
Called for them on their
to the "May Too"
or Standard 01l number one
residence for dinner.
Mr. and Mrs. F1 tzsimmons (he was Yale
"Shef"1916)
to nearly all Amerioans who visit Chungking.
opposite side of the river fron Chungking on
top of a hill
height of Shelving Rock at Lake George.
The girls were all
about the ride up in sedan chairs,
their first
experience with
that form of transport kakk vehicle.
Fitzsimmons had very
fully suggested that 1
should order a four man chair
for myself and
chairs for the girls - but he hadn't
the girls!
all had four man ehairs.
